text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits a revision to IRM 4.26.7, Bank Secrecy Act, Bank Secrecy Act Penalties.
) Content updated to more fully address internal control requirements under IRM
) Penalty amounts have been changed to reﬂect annual inﬂationary adjustments in accordance with the Federal Civil Penalties Inﬂation Adjustment Act of
(FCPIA Act), as further amended by the Federal Civil Penalties Inﬂation Adjustment Act Improvements Act of

) Regulations state that the penalties covered by the FCPIA Act should be adjusted annually due to inﬂation. Due to this requirement, actual amounts for covered penalties have been removed. A the penalty adjustment and table,
updated to more fully address internal control requirements under IRM

Regulations state that the penalties covered by the FCPIA Act should be adjusted annually due to inﬂation. Due to this requirement, actual amounts for covered penalties have been removed. A link to the penalty adjustment and table, 31 CFR 1010.821, is provided.
Intended audience is employees of the Bank Secrecy Act Program in the Small Business/Self Employed Division, and can be referenced by all ﬁeld compliance personnel.

) Purpose. This IRM provides an overview of the penalties that may be assessed on both reporting and recordkeeping requirements of the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA). Other than the Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR) penalty, all other penalties are assessed by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN). An IRS examiner’s decision to refer case to Fi

EN for a potential civil monetary penalty will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. However, all IRS examiners should aware of the potential civil and criminal penalties to inform those examined. (

) Audience. The intended audience is employees of the Bank Secrecy Act Program in the Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Division, and can be referenced by all IRS personnel, including those working FBAR cases. (
) Policy Owner. The Director, SB/SE Specialty Examination Policy is respon- sible for overseeing the policy for conducting examinations under the Bank Secrecy Act. (
) Program Owner. The Director, SB/SE Specialty Examination is responsible ensuring examinations conducted under the Bank Secrecy Act are conducted with integrity and fairness to all. (

) Primary Stakeholders. SB/SE Specialty Examination BSA; SB/SE ters Exam, Specialty Exam Policy BSA; SB/SE Exam Quality & Technical Support, Field and Specialty Exam Quality; Chief Counsel, Division Counsel SB/SE. (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) Program Goals. The mission of the BSA Program (BSA) is to safeguard the ﬁnancial system from the abuses of ﬁnancial crime, including terrorist ﬁnancing, money laundering, and other illicit activity by providing ﬁnancial tutions top quality service to help them understand their obligations under BSA and to ensure BSA compliance with integrity and fairness to all. (

) The Department of the Treasury has primary responsibility for implementing and enforcing the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA). The Secretary of the Treasury delegated the authority to administer the BSA to the Director, Financial Enforcement Network (Fi
EN redelegated responsibility for assuring civil compliance with the law to various Federal agencies including the Internal Revenue Service. Treasury Directive
) delegates the responsibility to examine and compliance with the requirements of
CFR Chapter X, Financial Crimes forcement Network, Department Of The Treasury, for certain entities to the IRS. Fi
EN’s delegation is limited to “examining” for compliance with the requirements. Fi
EN retains all civil penalty authority, except for penalties assessed on violations of the Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), under
) The authority to enforce the FBAR reporting and recordkeeping requirements found at

EN to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue by Delegation Order

), Authority for investigating criminal violations, to investigate all criminal viola- tions of the Bank Secrecy Act except those with respect to Form

(d), Criminal Penalty Not Exclusive of Civil Penalty. IRM
, Parallel Civil & Criminal Referrals, provides guidance on how to make the multaneous referrals. (
) Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is the executive responsible for BSA examination policy and procedures. (
) Director, Examination - Specialty Examination is the executive responsible BSA examination operational compliance. (
) Chief, BSA Examination is responsible for ensuring general information basic BSA examiner responsibilities and IRM sections is communicated to carried out by BSA examiners. (
) Chief, Examination is responsible for ensuring FBAR information is cated to and examiners audit for FBAR requirements. (
) Chief, Criminal Investigation is responsible for investigating criminal of the BSA. (

database contains reports to monitor the current year’s work as well as speciﬁc programs. These reports provide Headquarters and Field Examination with timely and reliable information. , known as the Secrecy Act (BSA), and the related regulations at

CFR Chapter X, Crimes Enforcement Network, Department of the Treasury, provide for civil criminal penalties as well as forfeiture of assets. BSA penalties depend on type of entity, the type of Anti-Money Laundering program, reporting or keeping violation involved, and the degree of intent. (
) Civil penalties, except for penalties assessed on requirements of the Report Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), are assessed by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN). FBAR assessment authority is delegated to the IRS. The examiner’s decision to refer a case to Fi
EN for potential civil monetary penalty will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. The general standard for a Fi
EN referral is “signiﬁcant” BSA violation(s) or AML program deﬁciencies. This, along with indications of willful behavior, may warrant a referral to Fi
EN. Referral procedures are located IRM

EN’s role includes evaluating the circumstances of the alleged and determining whether some type of civil action, including seeking the sition of a civil monetary penalty, should be taken against the person or ﬁnancial institution. (

, Civil penalties, provides overall civil penalty provisions for tions of the BSA and for violations of certain related statutes. It provides authority for assessing penalties when regulations for those penalties have been issued. The penalties apply to violations of the BSA itself, the under the BSA, or any geographic targeting or special measures order issued by Treasury, as well as penalties for taking certain actions, such as with the intent to evade BSA reporting or recordkeeping requirements. (
, Civil penalties, issued under the authority of
is the primary penalty regulation for all penalties assessed before August
It addresses civil penalties arising from violations of the BSA reporting and recordkeeping requirements, as well as structuring penalties. (
) The Federal Civil Penalties Inﬂation Adjustment Act of
(FCPIA Act) mandates that penalties be adjusted annually for inﬂation. For penalties assessed after August
EN must set forth adjusted maximum penalty amounts for each civil monetary penalty within its jurisdiction subject the FCPIA Act. The adjusted civil monetary penalty amounts at
, Penalty adjustment and table, supersede the amounts published authorizing the assessment of penalties.

criminal penalties as well as forfeiture of assets. BSA penalties depend on the type of entity, the type of Anti-Money Laundering program, reporting or record- keeping violation involved, and the degree of intent. Civil penalties, except for penalties assessed on requirements of the Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), are assessed by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN). FBAR assessment authority is delegated to the IRS. The examiner’s decision to refer a case to Fi
EN for a potential civil monetary penalty will depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case. The general standard for a Fi
EN referral is “signiﬁcant” BSA violation(s) or AML program deﬁciencies. This, along with indications of willful behavior, may warrant a referral to Fi
EN. Referral procedures are located at IRM

31 CFR 1010.820, Civil penalties, issued under the authority of 31 USC 5321 is the primary penalty regulation for all penalties assessed before August 2, 2016. It addresses civil penalties arising from violations of the BSA reporting and recordkeeping requirements, as well as structuring penalties.
) For penalties that have both a ﬁxed and a non-ﬁxed component, the civil monetary penalty amounts at
apply only to the ﬁxed amounts. For example, the penalty for willful FBAR failures is the greater of $
% of the account balance at the time of the violation. The civil monetary penalty inﬂation adjustment amount at

) Penalties that lack a stated dollar amount and are instead written solely as functions of violations are not subject to adjustment under the FCPIA Act. For example, the penalty for structuring a transaction to circumvent a BSA reporting requirement is the amount of coin and currency involved in the trans- action. See
EN is required to adjust each civil monetary penalty provided by law within their jurisdiction by the inﬂation adjust- ment and publish each such adjustment in the Federal Register.
If the Penalty Adjustment Table at
, Penalty Adjustment Table, is not current, examiners should check the Federal Register to see the inﬂation adjusted rate has been published. Penalties subject to adjustment are listed at

and include penalties related to: • Recordkeeping violations for funds transfer by an insured depository institution • Willful or grossly negligent recordkeeping violations • Failure to terminate correspondent relationship with foreign banks • General civil penalty provisions for willful violations of the BSA ments • Foreign ﬁnancial agency transactions which are non-willful • Foreign ﬁnancial agency transactions which are willful • Negligent violations by ﬁnancial institutions and nonﬁnancial trades or businesses • Pattern of negligent activity by ﬁnancial institutions or nonﬁnancial trades or businesses • Violations of certain due diligence requirements, prohibition on corre- spondent accounts for shell banks, and special measures • Civil penalties for failure to register as a money services business
(h) provided for a penalty for each negligent violation of any requirement of the Bank Secrecy (BSA). The penalty amount could not exceed $
Negligence is further discussed in IRM
The penalty may be assessed against any ﬁnancial institution or trade or business which negligently violates any provision of
, Civil penalties. For penalties assessed after August
, the negligence penalties are subject to annual inﬂationary adjustment under the FCPIA Act.

Note: If the Penalty Adjustment Table at 31 CFR 1010.821, Penalty Adjustment and Table, is not current, examiners should check the Federal Register to see if the inﬂation adjusted rate has been published.

) Where the violation is willful, the penalty depends on the Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) requirement violated. There are different penalties for recordkeeping, reporting, and Anti-Money Laundering program violations, as well as for types of violations, such as failure by a Money Services Business (MSB) to register. (
) Within the types of willful violations, there are variations in penalties as depending on the provision violated. (

) A penalty may be assessed upon any person to which the regulation or any person willfully causing a violation of the regulations, and if such is a partnership, corporation, or other entity, upon any partner, director, or employee thereof who willfully or through gross negligence participates the violation identiﬁed at

A penalty may be assessed upon any person to which the regulation applies, or any person willfully causing a violation of the regulations, and if such person is a partnership, corporation, or other entity, upon any partner, director, officer, or employee thereof who willfully or through gross negligence participates in the violation identiﬁed at 31 USC 5321(a) other than an FBAR violation. For an

, the penalties are subject to the inﬂationary adjustments under the FCPIA Act. The ﬁrst table is for willful violation of record keeping penalties and the second table is for willful violation of reporting requirement penalties.

, Reports of transactions with foreign ﬁnancial agencies, establish procedures under which the Secretary of the Treasury may issue regulations requiring designated ﬁnancial institutions to report certain ﬁnancial transactions with designated foreign ﬁnancial A civil penalty not to exceed the greater of the amount of the transaction to exceed $

, Records of certain domestic transactions, and

, Reports of certain domestic coin and currency transactions, allow the Secretary, upon the Secretary’s own initiative or at the request of an priate federal or state law enforcement official, to issue a Geographical Targeting Order (GTO). A GTO requires a domestic ﬁnancial institution or group of domestic ﬁnancial institutions in a geographic area, and any other person participating in the type of transaction, to ﬁle a report in the manner and to the extent speciﬁed in the order, if it is found that reasonable exist for concluding that additional recordkeeping and/or reporting are necessary to carry out the purposes of the BSA. A civil penalty not to exceed the greater of the amount of the transaction (not to exceed or $
may be assessed upon any domestic ﬁnancial institution, and any partner, director, officer, or employee thereof who willfully participates in the violation. See

31 USC 5314 and 31 CFR 1010.360, Reports of transactions with foreign ﬁnancial agencies, establish procedures under which the Secretary of the Treasury may issue regulations requiring designated ﬁnancial institutions to report certain ﬁnancial transactions with designated foreign ﬁnancial A civil penalty not to exceed the greater of the amount of the transaction (not to exceed $100,000), or $25,000 may be assessed upon any person who willfully violates the requirement to report. See 31 CFR 1010.820(g)(1).

A, Special measures for jurisdictions, ﬁnancial institutions, international transactions, or types of accounts of primary money laundering concern, for one or more domestic ﬁnancial institutions and domestic ﬁnancial agencies, may be required after a ﬁnding by the Secretary that a jurisdiction outside of the US, a ﬁnancial institu- tion operating outside of the US, or a transaction within, or involving, a jurisdiction outside of the US is of primary money laundering concern. Special Measures for some countries appear in the regulations in Subpart F, Special Standards of Diligence: Prohibitions; and Special Measures. Example:
, Special measures against Burma. A civil money penalty in an amount equal to not less than

) The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized by
), Transaction Violation, to impose a civil money penalty on any person who structures, or attempts to structure, a transaction with the intent to evade a Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) requirement. (

) A civil penalty may be assessed up to the amount of coins and currency involved in the structured transaction(s). The amount of any civil penalty assessed shall be reduced by the amount of any forfeiture to the US in nection with the transactions for which the penalty was imposed. See

, Structuring, contains a complete discussion of the: • Law which prohibits structuring, • Procedures on how to identify structured transactions, • Examples of structured transactions, and • Examination techniques to identify structured transactions. (

) Structuring is deﬁned as a person, acting alone, or in conjunction with, or behalf of, other persons, conducts or attempts to conduct one or more tions in currency, in any amount, at one or more ﬁnancial institutions, on or more days, in any manner, for the purpose of evading a reporting or keeping requirement of the BSA. ), General Powers of the Secretary, allows the Secretary of the Treasury to require a class of domestic ﬁnancial institutions or nonﬁnancial trades or businesses to maintain appropriate procedures to ensure with the Bank Secrecy Act and its regulations or to guard against money laun- dering. (

(h), Anti-Money Laundering Programs, requires all ﬁnancial insti- tutions to establish an anti-money laundering (AML) program with minimum requirements; however, regulations have not been adopted for some types of ﬁnancial institutions and they are currently exempted from this requirement. Those ﬁnancial institutions required to have AML programs appear in the lations at
CFR Chapter X, Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, Department of the Treasury.
, Exempted anti-money ing programs for certain ﬁnancial institutions, provides permanent and temporary exemptions from this requirement. (

), Temporary exemption for certain ﬁnancial institutions, provides a temporary exemption to the requirement to develop and implement an AML program to a bank that is not subject to regulation by a Federal func- tional regulator. The IRS is not deﬁned as a Federal functional regulator under
(r), Federal functional regulator. Consequently, a credit union under IRS authority is temporarily exempt from the requirement to have an AML program. (

, Customer identiﬁcation programs for banks, savings asso- ciations, credit unions, and certain non-Federally regulated banks, requires these ﬁnancial institutions to have a written customer identiﬁcation program.

) A penalty may be assessed upon any domestic ﬁnancial institution or non- ﬁnancial trade or business, and a partner, director, officer, or employee of the domestic ﬁnancial institution or non-ﬁnancial trade or business who willfully violates this requirement. A separate violation occurs for each day the violation continues and at each office, branch, or place of business at which a violation occurs or continues.
For penalties assessed after August 1, 2016, the penalty is subject to the inﬂa- tionary adjustments under the FCPIA Act.

The failure to comply with the MSB registration requirement includes failure to retain a copy of the registration or agent list. See

, Registration of Money Services Busi- nesses, deﬁnes an “owner or controlling person” for purposes of to register to include, for a corporation, “the largest single shareholder”. The instructions also provide that if two or more persons own equal numbers of shares of a corporation, they may enter into an agreement to determine who will register the corporation. provide ditional information. The law states that any person who fails to comply with any requirement of the law may be liable for a civil penalty. (

) Civil willfulness means that the violation is voluntary, rather than accidental unconscious. Civil willfulness includes when a person acts “with willful blindness” to the obvious or known consequences of the person’s actions. willfulness also includes when a person acts recklessly, which means the person’s actions took an unjustiﬁably high risk that is either known or so obvious that it should be known. (
) In determining intent, generally one looks to the knowledge of the person involved. This includes knowledge of the facts involved and knowledge of requirements relating to those facts. (
) Intent is determined by analyzing all the facts and circumstances of the case and it is often shown by circumstantial evidence. The BSA examiner must oughly document facts on the issue of intent. (
) Negligence is usually deﬁned as the failure to use the care that a person would use in the same or similar circumstances. (

) There are two principal areas where a reasonable person would exercise for ﬁnancial reporting and recordkeeping. A reasonable business person normally: a. Exercise care to learn about legal requirements in his area of b. Exercise care to see that his business had sufficient internal controls meet those requirements. (
) When normal business care is not exercised in one or both areas, there is a case for negligence. (

) Negligence is the lack of reasonable cause for a failure to use the care normally expected in the same or similar circumstances. For additional tions on the type of facts that establish negligence, see IRM
, Penalty Handbook, Introduction and Penalty Relief.
Each day a violation continues constitutes a separate violation.
Negligence is usually deﬁned as the failure to use the care that a reasonable person would use in the same or similar circumstances.

) Civil willfulness means that the violation is voluntary, rather than accidental unconscious. Civil willfulness includes when a person acts with willful to the obvious or know consequences of the person’s actions. Civil also includes when a person acts recklessly, which means that the person’s actions took an unjustiﬁably high risk that is either known or so obvious that should be known. (
) The government need only show that the ﬁnancial institution or individual with either recklessness or willful blindness in a civil enforcement action
), Civil penalties. The government need not show that the entity or individual had knowledge that the conduct violated the BSA or with an improper motive or bad purpose. (

) The ﬁrst step to establish “recklessness” or “willful blindness” is establishing that the entity or individuals had knowledge of the law or took deliberate actions to avoid conﬁrming their requirements under the BSA. Evidence of intentional act or a conscious effort to avoid learning of their legal duty with knowledge that the transactions occurred is an excellent indicator of fulness. Knowledge of the law may be established in several ways: a. Notiﬁcation by the IRS, including receipt of Letter

, Bank Secrecy Act Requirements Notiﬁcation Letter, prior BSA examinations, and tional visits. b. Prior BSA ﬁling history. c. Actions by the entity, including development of an AML program, previ- ously ﬁled reports, registration with Fi
EN. d. Work history of owners, officers, and employees. e. Education provided by the principal(s) to their agents and the of training. f. Education or training by their business community. (

) The second step to establish recklessness or willful blindness is evaluating dicators of willfulness. Factors to consider when evaluating indicators of willfulness are: a. Failure to report a transaction which is logged or identiﬁed on a report. b. Failure to keep records. c. Altering records. d. Misleading the examiner. For example, a casino that states they do accept “wires in” and bank statements identify large wires in from lished patrons. e. Failure to report on speciﬁc customers. For example, an entity ﬁles on all customers except one, or an employee is identiﬁed on an report aiding a customer to structure a transaction and compliance ignores the report due to a personal relationship. f. Failure of the entity’s owners to make a conscious effort to determine what the law requires when starting a new business. (

, Prohibition of unlicensed money transmitting businesses, prohibits anyone to knowingly conduct any unlicensed money transmitting business, whether or not they knew that the operation was required to be licensed or that operation without a license was a criminal offense. A person who violates this offense knowingly conducts, controls, manages, supervises, directs or owns all or part of an unlicensed money transmitting business by operating without a state license, failing to comply with federal Money Business (MSB) registration requirements, or transferring money knowing the funds transmitted were criminally derived or intended to promote or support some unlawful activity. Note: The term “money transmitting business” means any business other than the United States Postal Service which provides check cashing, currency exchange, or money transmitting or remittance services, or issues or redeems money orders, travelers’ checks, and other similar instruments or any other person who engages as a business in the transmission of funds, including any person who engages as a business in an informal money transfer system or any network of people who engage as a business in tating the transfer of money domestically or internationally outside of the conventional ﬁnancial institutions system. ), Civil Forfeiture, provides for civil forfeiture proceedings. The code provision is quite broad. Any property involved in a violation of
, Reports on domestic coins and currency transactions,
, Reports on exporting and importing monetary instruments, or

, Structuring transactions to evade reporting requirement prohibited, or any spiracy to commit such violation, and any property traceable to any such violation or conspiracy, may be seized and forfeited to the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury has discretionary authority to remit or mitigate the forfeiture. (

, Forfeiture of currency or monetary instruments, is narrower in that it mentions neither the CTR nor the structuring transactional amounts. This regulation provides only that any currency or other monetary instruments, which are in the process of any transportation and for which a CMIR is required under

, Reports of transportation of currency or monetary instruments, are subject to seizure and forfeiture to the United States if the report has not been ﬁled or contains material omissions or misstatements. (
) Amounts seized and forfeited reduce penalties assessed for violation of the reporting requirements regarding exporting and importing monetary under
